items.content_html:
copies of the same class share their underlying data, meaning that changing one changes them all, whereas structs always have their own unique data, and changing a copy does not affect the others.

I found this explanation confusing until I took the test and realized the difference.

In JS, creating an object or class instance and assigning it to two different variables matches the ‚Äúcopy‚Äù semantics above (the variable is a reference to the object).

The ‚Äústruct‚Äù behavior (by value) is how primitives work in JS (string, bool, etc.). Objects never work this way.

Day 12 over! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

I found this explanation confusing until I took the test and realized the difference.

In JS, creating an object or class instance and assigning it to two different variables matches the ‚Äúcopy‚Äù semantics above (the variable is a reference to the object).

The ‚Äústruct‚Äù behavior (by value) is how primitives work in JS (string, bool, etc.). Objects never work this way.

items.content_html: Structs (part two) with a checkpoint‚Ä¶ day 11 was pretty straightforward! #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text: Structs (part two) with a checkpoint‚Ä¶ day 11 was pretty straightforward! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
Structs, mutating on methods, computed properties, property observers, custom initializers‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs a lot but it was pretty easy to get through.

I think the only ‚Äúnew‚Äù concept (coming from JavaScript) was marking methods as mutating.

Day 10 done so 10% of the way there! #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text:
Structs, `mutating` on methods, computed properties, property observers, custom initializers‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs a lot but it was pretty easy to get through.

I think the only ‚Äúnew‚Äù concept (coming from JavaScript) was marking methods as `mutating`.

Day 10 done so 10% of the way there! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
Dropping the parenthesis when calling functions with a closure blows my mind:

team.filter { $0.hasPrefix("T") }

The equivalent in JS:

team.filter($0 => $0.startsWith("T"))

Woo! The checkpoint test actually didn‚Äôt take me very long to complete.

Day 9 in the books! #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text:
Dropping the parenthesis when calling functions with a closure blows my mind:

```swift
team.filter { $0.hasPrefix("T") }
```

The equivalent in JS:

```js
team.filter($0 => $0.startsWith("T"))
```

Woo! The checkpoint test actually didn‚Äôt take me very long to complete.

Day 9 in the books! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
Really interesting that Swift has do, but it‚Äôs not what you think!

do {
    try throwingFunction1()
    nonThrowingFunction1()
} catch {
    print("Handle errors here")
}

In JS, that do would be try and no ‚Äútry‚Äù is required before a throwing function.

Day 8 in the books! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

Awesome to me that this is valid:

func record(age: Int) { }
func record(year: Int) { }

Naming internal and external parameters separately is interesting too:

func square(of num: Int) -> Int {
    return num * num
}

let result = square(of: 4)

Day 7 in the books! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

Day 6 is all about for and while loops.

I‚Äôll be excited to learn the .map and .filter equivalents. I rarely use for loops in JS and have only used while a couple times in my career. ü´¢

I wasn‚Äôt expecting to do FizzBuzz for the checkpoint test. There‚Äôs a first time for everything! #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text:
Day 6 is all about `for` and `while` loops.

I‚Äôll be excited to learn the `.map` and `.filter` equivalents. I rarely use `for` loops in JS and have only used `while` a couple times in my career. ü´¢

I wasn‚Äôt expecting to do FizzBuzz for the checkpoint test. There‚Äôs a first time for everything! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
My comment about no === in Swift was incorrect, thanks Matt!

I should know that a beginner course isn‚Äôt going to immediately explain referential equality, that won‚Äôt make sense yet.

https://mastodon.social/@mattiem/113203444245305184
items.content_text:
My comment about no `===` in Swift was incorrect, thanks Matt!

I should know that a beginner course isn‚Äôt going to immediately explain referential equality, that won‚Äôt make sense yet.

https://mastodon.social/@mattiem/113203444245305184

items.content_html:
No === in Swift (just ==) is nice!

Enums being comparable is pretty cool too.

And switch statements‚Ä¶ is this the day I confess that I tend not to use them in JavaScript? Swift‚Äôs fallthrough syntax seems much safer than JS needing a break for each case.

Day 5 done! #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text:
No `===` in Swift (just `==`) is nice!

Enums being comparable is pretty cool too.

And `switch` statements‚Ä¶ is this the day I confess that I tend not to use them in JavaScript? Swift‚Äôs `fallthrough` syntax seems much safer than JS needing a `break` for each `case`.

Day 5 done! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
This is really interesting:

let name: String
// ‚Ä¶
name = "Chasen"
// Allowed once

In JavaScript, the ‚Äúequivalent‚Äù (using const) requires an initial value and doesn‚Äôt let you reassign it later. I like that Swift allows it be undefined and assigned just once.

Day 4 done! #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text:
This is really interesting:

```swift
let name: String
// ‚Ä¶
name = "Chasen"
// Allowed once
```

In JavaScript, the ‚Äúequivalent‚Äù (using `const`) _requires_ an initial value and doesn‚Äôt let you reassign it later. I like that Swift allows it be undefined and assigned just once.

Day 4 done! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
Coming from JS, there are some small differences in array and dictionary syntax. This really stood out to me (as nice and explicit):

let olympics = [
    2016: "Rio de Janeiro",
    2021: "Tokyo",
    2024: "Paris"
]

print(olympics[2020, default: "Unknown"])

Day 3 in the books! #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text:
Coming from JS, there are some small differences in array and dictionary syntax. This really stood out to me (as nice and explicit):

```swift
let olympics = [
    2016: "Rio de Janeiro",
    2021: "Tokyo",
    2024: "Paris"
]

print(olympics[2020, default: "Unknown"])
```

Day 3 in the books! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
This has a bug‚Ä¶ can you spot it?

let temperature = 29
let converted = (temperature * 9 / 5) + 32
print("Celsius: \(temperature)")
print("Fahrenheit: \(converted)")

I thought the compiler might warn when losing precision like this, but I guess not!

Day 2 in the books! #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text:
This has a bug‚Ä¶ can you spot it?

```swift
let temperature = 29
let converted = (temperature * 9 / 5) + 32
print("Celsius: \(temperature)")
print("Fahrenheit: \(converted)")
```

I thought the compiler might warn when losing precision like this, but I guess not!

Day 2 in the books! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
I‚Äôm going to compare Swift to JavaScript a lot as I get up to speed.

Seems like Swift‚Äôs var == let (in JS) and let == const. I‚Äôm sure that won‚Äôt trip me up‚Ä¶

Interesting that 1_00__00___00____00 is valid in Swift (JS only allows one separator per digit, not multiple).
items.content_text:
I‚Äôm going to compare Swift to JavaScript *a lot* as I get up to speed.

Seems like Swift‚Äôs var == let (in JS) and let == const. I‚Äôm sure that won‚Äôt trip me up‚Ä¶

Interesting that `1_00__00___00____00` is valid in Swift (JS only allows one separator per digit, not multiple).
